Production of bio-paraffin from solvent-free deoxygenation of palm biodiesel over ZrO2-supported nickel phosphide catalysts Natthawan Prasongthum Conceptualization Investigation Formal analysis Writing – review & editing a Amornrat Suemanotham Investigation Visualization a Wanchana Sisuthog Investigation a Yoothana Thanmongkhon Writing – review & editing Project administration a Prasert Reubroycharoen Writing – review & editing b Lalita Attanatho Conceptualization Funding acquisition Writing – review & editing a ⁎ a Expert Centre of Innovative Clean Energy and Environment, Thailand Institute of Scientific and Technological Research (TISTR), Khlong Luang, Pathum Thani 12120, Thailand Expert Centre of Innovative Clean Energy and Environment, Thailand Institute of Scientific and Technological Research (TISTR) Khlong Luang Pathum Thani 12120 Thailand Expert Centre of Innovative Clean Energy and Environment, Thailand Institute of Scientific and Technological Research (TISTR), Khlong Luang, Pathum Thani 12120, Thailand b Department of Chemical Technology, Faculty of Science, Chulalongkorn University, Bangkok 10330, Thailand Department of Chemical Technology, Faculty of Science, Chulalongkorn University Bangkok 10330 Thailand Department of Chemical Technology, Faculty of Science, Chulalongkorn University, Bangkok 10330, Thailand ⁎ Corresponding author. This study investigated the effects of Ni/P molar ratio on nickel phosphide species and on the catalytic activity on solvent-free deoxygenation of palm biodiesel to produce n-paraffins. ZrO2-supported nickel phosphide catalysts with different Ni/P molar ratio were synthesized and characterized through HRTEM, XPS, XRD, BET, NH3-TPD, and H2-TPR analysis techniques, to give an insight into the correlation of the catalyst structure and its performance. The formation of different types of nickel phosphide phases when preparing the catalyst with different Ni/P molar ratio was observed. Only Ni2P was formed with Ni/P molar ratio of 1, while Ni2P and Ni12P5 were detected when Ni/P molar ratio was 2. With further increasing Ni/P molar ratios to 3 and 4, new phases of Ni0 and Ni3P were formed in addition to those of Ni2P and Ni12P5. NixP/ZrO2 exhibited excellent catalytic performance for deoxygenation of palm biodiesel mainly via decarbonylation/decarboxylation pathways, achieving the high FAME conversion of 50.2–88.0% and n-alkane selectivity of 65.0–95.4%. Conversion and alkane selectivity of the catalysts followed the sequence: Ni3P/ZrO2 ≈ Ni4P/ZrO2 > Ni2P/ZrO2 > Ni1P/ZrO2 > Ni/ZrO2, respectively. These results suggested that Ni/P molar ratio had significantly affected on catalytic performance, which was associated with the type of nickel phosphide phase, metal dispersion, metal particle size, as well as electron density on Ni site. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Palm biodiesel Hydrodeoxygenation Nickel phosphide Ni/P ratio N-paraffins Data availability The authors do not have permission to share data. 1 Introduction In recent year, biofuels have been proposed as a sustainable resource to complement traditional petroleum-derived liquid fuels. Biodiesel, consisting of fatty acid methyl esters (FAMEs), obtained from animal fat and vegetable oils via transesterification is by far, the predominant biofuel at the present time due to its nontoxic and sulfur free characters. Biodiesel combustion generally results in lower particulate matter (over 50%), unburned hydrocarbons (45–67%), and carbon monoxide (up to 84%) in exhaust emissions compared to fossil diesel [1]. Despite biodiesel technology ready for commercial application, it usually exhibits relatively high freezing point, which is mostly ascribed to its high oxygen content and unsaturated C-C bonds [2]. Such properties make it not fully compatible with diesel engines. Catalytic hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) is an approach to remove oxygen from oxygenated feedstocks. Through the HDO, biodiesel is converted to a mixture of hydrocarbons mainly composed of a high concentration of normal-paraffins. These hydrocarbons mostly consist of a carbon range of diesel fuels which can be used in unmodified diesel engines. They also can be promising alternative chemical feedstocks for petrochemical, cosmetic, pharmaceutical and food industries. The deoxygenation of biodiesel can be achieved by hydrogenation of unsaturated bonds and further removal of the oxygen by releasing H2O, and CO or CO2 in case of decarbonylation/decarboxylation (DCO/DCO2) [2]. To date, many studies have been investigated HDO using different types of solvents such as water, dodecane and toluene [3,4]. However, for the industrial application, the solvent-free synthesis of paraffinic product should be developed. Enhanced solvent-free synthesis of paraffinic product has been observed not only noble metals (Pt, Pt–Re, Rh or Pd) but also non-noble metals (Ni, Co) and metal sulfides (Ni-Mo sulfide, Co-Mo sulfide) [5,6]. Although the metal sulfides show good performance for HDO and have been already used in commercial HDO processes, they require a continuous flow of S-containing compounds to maintain their activity and stability. This could cause the formation of undesirable S-containing products, which lead to the need of a purification step [7]. From this point of view, development of non-sulfide catalysts for HDO is of great significance. Compared to the sulfide catalysts, noble metal catalysts exhibit higher activity and stability for HDO process, but their high cost limit their wide practical application. As an alternative, Ni-based catalysts have also received great attention. However, they have high activity for methanation and cracking, which increase H2 consumption and reduce carbon yield [8]. Recently, transition metal phosphides have been reported as promising catalysts for HDO due to their low cost and low activity for methanation and cracking. In particular, Ni-P catalyst have been studied extensively to deoxygenation of ester derivatives of fatty acids [9–11]. The properties of the support can influence the structure of active phase (such as dispersion and electron property) and the surface acid/base properties of the catalyst [8]. Compared to zeolite, γ-Al2O3 and ZrO2 exhibit moderate surface acidity for promoting the HDO reactions and preventing extending cracking [12]. However, γ-Al2O3 are not so suitable supports for transition metal phosphides catalysts since it interacts strongly with the phosphorus leading to the formation of AlPO4. For this reason, ZrO2 seems to be quite attractive support for the HDO reactions. ZrO2 has an excellent anti-coking performance due to its reducible property which contains a significant concentration of oxygen vacancies to facilitate the concerted adsorption of carboxylic groups in fatty acid and H2 activation [13]. ZrO2-supported nickel phosphide has been investigated for the HDO of m-cresol. Gonçalves et al. [14] reported that the activity of catalyst depended on the nickel phases (Ni, Ni2P and Ni12P5). Ni2P catalyst was more active than N12P5 for HDO of m-cresol. Despite a single phase of nickel phosphide, utilization of mixed phase nickel phosphides of Ni2P and Ni12P5 was found to be the eﬀective catalysts for HDO reaction [15]. In contrast, a catalyst containing Ni3P and Ni12P5 exhibited excellent activity for DCO reaction [16]. Moreover, the activity of nickel phosphide was influenced by the nature of catalyst support, while the formation of different nickel phases, Ni2P, Ni12P5, Ni3P depended on Ni/P ratio values [14,17]. Therefore, the effects of Ni/P molar ratio and the role of different Ni sites on deoxygenation of biodiesel is worth investigating to obtain insight into the optimal catalyst to produce bio-paraffins. Thus, this study aimed at exploring and understanding the effects of Ni/P molar ratio on nickel phosphide species and on the catalytic activity on solvent-free deoxygenation of palm biodiesel to produce n-paraffins. ZrO2-supported nickel phosphide with different Ni/P molar ratio was prepared and characterized by advanced techniques (such as HRTEM and XPS) to give insight into the correlation of catalyst structure and its performance. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials The reactant materials were zirconia (ZrO2, 99 wt%, Kanto Chemical Co., Inc.); nickel nitrate hexahydrate (Ni(NO3)20.6 H2O, 97 wt%, Laboratory UNILAB reagent); di-ammonium hydrogen phosphate ((NH4)2HPO4, 99 wt%, Qrec, Newzealand), nitric acid (HNO3, 70 wt%, Sigma-Aldrich) and palm biodiesel which kindly provided by BBGI Bio Diesel Company Limited. The compositions of palm biodiesel were as follows: palmitic acid (C16:0) 44.28%; stearic acid (C18:0) 4.13%; oleic acid (C18:1) 39.86%; and linoleic acid (C18:2) 9.62%. 2.2 Catalyst preparation A series of NixP/ZrO2 bifunctional catalysts with the Ni/P molar ratios of 1, 2, 3 and 4 were prepared by wet impregnation method at a Ni loading of 10 wt%. Briefly, (NH4)2HPO4 and Ni(NO3)2 6H2O were dissolved in 20 ml of DI water and stirred. Then, a yellow-green precipitate was formed. A 0.5 M HNO3 was added dropwise to dissolve the precipitate. Finally, ZrO2 support was introduced into the solution, followed by stirring for 3 h at 75 °C. The resultant precursor was then dried at 110 °C for 12 h and calcined at 550 °C for 4 h. The calcined products were assigned as Ni1P/ZrO2, Ni2P/ZrO2, Ni3P/ZrO2 and Ni4P/ZrO2, based on the Ni/P ratios employed in synthesis. For comparison, Ni/ZrO2 was prepared by wet impregnation of ZrO2 with an aqueous solution of Ni(NO3)2 6H2O to obtain a final Ni loading of 10 wt%, followed by drying at 110 °C for 12 h and calcination at 550 °C for 4 h. In addition, the synthesized catalysts were subsequently reduced at 550 °C for 4 h under H2 gas. Afterwards, the samples were cooled down to ambient temperature under N2 gas, and then passivated for 18 h under a 0.5 vol% O2/N2 flow. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The surface areas of the catalysts were obtained with nitrogen adsorption from Micromeristics ASAP 2020. The morphologies of the samples were observed by transmission electron microscopy (TEM) using TEM JEM-2100 Plus. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the samples were defined using a SmartLab (Rigaku Corporation, Japan) equipped with Cu-Kα as a source operated at 50 kV and 50 mA in the range of 20–80 at a scan rate of 2.0 s−1. NH3 temperature-programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) and H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) were carried out on a Bel-Cat B instrument. For NH3-TPD, approximately 0.1 g of the passivated sample was initially pretreated at 800 °C for 1 h under He flow, followed by cooling down to 50 °C. NH3 (5%) was passed through the test sample at a flow rate of 30 ml/min for 30 min. Then, the samples were heated up to 800 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C /min. H2-TPR was carried out with 5 mg of sample in the presence of 10 vol% H2/N2 flow (50 ml/min) at a heating rate of 10 °C /min from 50 °C to 900 °C. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed on a Kratos/Axis ultra DLD spectrometer with an Al-Kα radiation. The binding energies were determined with the contaminant carbon (C1s at 284.6 eV). The amount of carbon deposition on the spent catalysts was determined using a TG/DTG−STA449F3 (NETZSCH) instrument under a flow of air at a heating rate of 10 ºC/min. 2.4 Catalyst testing The HDO catalytic activity was carried out in a 100 ml batch reactor (Parr model 4598). Prior to catalytic testing, 1 g of passivated catalyst and 20 g of palm biodiesel were loaded into the reactor. The reactor was purged with N2 several times to eliminate oxygen remaining in the system, and then pressurized with H2 (40 bar). The temperature was heated up to 350 °C and maintained at this temperature for 5 h under a stirring speed of 300 rpm. At the end of reaction time, the reactor was cooled to ambient temperature. The gaseous products were collected using a gas sampling bag and analyzed by gas chromatography (GC) (Agilent 7890 A), using GS-Oxyplot, HP-AL/S, Molsieve 13X, and Porapak Q columns. The liquid product was collected, separated from the catalyst by filtration, and quantitatively analyzed by GC with a flame ionization detector (FID, Agilent 7890 A) equipped with a DB-5HT column by using Tricaprylin as an internal standard. To ensure the reproducibility of experimental results, all experiments were performed in duplicate with less than 5% relative errors of duplicated data. FAME conversion, product selectivity, degree of HDO and degree of decarbonylation/decarboxylation (DCO/DCO2) reactions were defined as follows: (1) Conversion (%) = (mole of converted FAME/mole of FAME in palm biodiesel) x 100% (2) Selectivity (%)= (mole of the product/total mole of products) x 100% (3) HDO (%) = (total mole of n-alkanes (n-C16 and n-C18) in product/mole of FAME in palm biodiesel) x 100% (4) DCO/DCO2 (%) = (total mole of n-alkanes (n-C15 and n-C17) in product/mole of FAME in palm biodiesel) x 100% Turnover frequency (TOF) was defined as the moles of FAME converted per mole of metal per reaction time, according to the following equation. (5) TOF (s−1) = (conversion x mole of FAME)/ (mole of metal x reaction time) 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization Table 1 shows the surface area (SBET), pore size, and pore volume of the Ni-impregnated catalysts. The SBET of the Ni/ZrO2 and NixP/ZrO2 with different Ni/P molar ratios were 5.1 and 5.7–7.2 m2/g, respectively. The Ni/ZrO2 and NixP/ZrO2 catalysts exhibited markedly low surface area and pore volume, implying that it was a non-porous structure. Table 1 also shows the actual contents of Ni and P of the catalysts which examined by ICP-OES analysis. The resulting Ni/P molar ratios were slightly higher than the theoretical ratios used in the synthesis. The XRD pattern of the ZrO2 support ( Fig. 1) confirms the presence of the monoclinic ZrO2 crystal phase (JCPDS 01–074–0815). As for the Ni/ZrO2 catalyst, the small peaks at 2θ of 45.3 and 51.7 were ascribed to metallic Ni (JCPDS 01–078–7533), while the XRD patterns of the ZrO2-supported nickel phosphide catalysts exhibited the various phases of nickel phosphides including Ni0, Ni2P, Ni3P and Ni12P5 [14]. The nickel phosphide catalyst with Ni/P ratio of 1, the XRD results revealed only Ni2P diffraction peak at 41.8 (JCPDS 01–074–1385). As the Ni/P molar ratio increased to 2, the peaks due to Ni12P5 at 2θ of 47.2 and 52.6 (JCPDS 00–022–1190) were detected besides Ni2P. With further increasing Ni/P molar ratios to 3 and 4, new phases of Ni0 (JCPDS 01–078–7533) and Ni3P (JCPDS 00–034–0501) were formed in addition to those of Ni2P and Ni12P5. Fig. 2 illustrates the morphology of the reduced catalysts observed by TEM and the average particle sizes of the catalysts are listed in Table 1. The TEM picture shows the surface of ZrO2 was decorated by nickel and nickel phosphide species (dark spots), which are confirmed by EDS elemental mapping ( Fig. 3). The results clearly revealed that Ni/ZrO2 exhibited poor dispersion and a broad size distribution of Ni particle was observed with an average particle size of 95 nm. On the other hand, the nickel phosphide catalysts revealed a spherical shape with smaller metal particle sizes and well dispersion. The size of catalyst particles was in the range of 16 – 91 nm and tended to decrease with the decreasing of Ni/P molar ratios. In the HRTEM image of Ni/ZrO2, the interplanar distances of 0.205 nm was assigned to crystallographic planes Ni (111) [18]. As for the Ni1P/ZrO2 catalyst, the interplanar distances of 0.221 nm was observed, indicating the existence of Ni2P, which was consistent with the crystallographic plane determined by XRD. The interplanar distances for Ni3P/ZrO2 and Ni4P/ZrO2 indicated the coexistence of the Ni, Ni2P, Ni3P and Ni12P5 phases [18,19]. Representative NH3-TPD plots of the reduced catalysts are shown in Fig. 4, and the amount of total acid sites are presented in Table 1. The NH3-TPD plots of Ni/ZrO2 presents a less intense peak centered at 173 °C which was ascribed to weak Brønsted acid sites [17]. The intensity of this peak increased after adding P and the peak shifted toward to higher temperature, indicative of the increase in acid strength. As indicated in Table 1, the amount of desorbed NH3 increased with the decrease of Ni/P molar ratio. The NH3-TPD profile of Ni1P/ZrO2 showed a strong peak centered at 279 °C, besides the less intense peak at 173 °C. It ascribed to NH3 absorption by a positive charge on Ni site, which acted as Lewis acid sites because of a charge transfer from nickel to phosphorus. These results are in agreement with the results reported by Gonçalves et al. [14]. In addition, the intensity of NH3-TPD peak of Ni1P/ZrO2 exhibited higher than other samples. It was previously reported that the acidity of nickel phosphide catalyst was affected by the type of Ni atoms existed in nickel phosphide. Ni12P5 and Ni3P were less favorable to react with NH3 compared to Ni2P, thus their acid strengths were lower [25]. According to XRD results, the high Ni metal content in Ni/P favored to form Ni-rich phosphide (Ni12P5 and Ni3P), while the lower Ni content especially Ni/P molar ratio of 1 generated the formation of Ni2P. Therefore, the higher acidity of Ni1P/ZrO2 catalyst could be the consequence of the formation of Ni2P. Fig. 5 shows the reduction features of each catalyst. As indicated in Fig. 5, the Ni/ZrO2 catalyst showed a broad peak at around 300 °C, corresponding to the reduction of bulk NiO and NiOX species with a strong interaction with ZrO2 support [14]. As for the NixP/ZrO2 samples, the reduction peaks were significantly more complex and shifted towards a higher temperature compared to the Ni/ZrO2 catalyst. For the precursors with lower P contents, there is a number of overlapping of reduction peaks ranging from 300° to 650°C. These results were in good agreement with the previous report by Shi et al. At lower P contents, the catalyst may comprise more Ni compounds including nickel oxide and nickel phosphates, which led to the difference in reduction peaks. As the nickel oxide was easily reduced, its reduction peak took place at lower temperature, thus the minor broad peak appeared at 300–450 °C was probably ascribed to the reduction of NiO to Ni. Whereas the TPR peaks above 450 °C was assigned to the reduction of nickel phosphate due to the high thermally stable P-O bond. Moreover, within this temperature range, the initially formed Ni species could promote the adsorption and dissociation of H2 that spilled over to phosphate and facilitated its reduction to form phosphides [16]. For the precursors with higher P contents, the reduction peaks shifted to higher temperature, particularly the Ni/P molar ratio of 1 the sharp peak centered at 700 °C was observed corresponding to the reduction of nickel phosphate particles which had strong interaction with the ZrO2 support [20]. The H2 consumption values of catalysts are presented in Table 1. Compared to the Ni/ZrO2 catalyst, the nickel phosphide catalysts had higher H2 consumption, which was consistent with the report by Gonçalves et al. [14]. It revealed that NiO consumed 1 mol of H2 to convert to Ni0 (NiO + H2 → Ni + H2O), while nickel phosphide catalyst required 9 mol of H2 to generate 2 mol of Ni2P (4NiO + 9 H2 + P2O5 → 2Ni2P + 9 H2O) and 49 mol of H2 to generate 2 mol of Ni12P5 (24NiO + 49 H2 + 5 P2O5 → 2Ni12P5 + 49 H2O). The XPS profiles of the P 2p and Ni 2p regions of the reduced samples are presented in Fig. 6 and Fig. 7, respectively, and Ni 2p and P 2p binding energy values were summarized in Table 2. The binding energies of P 2p XPS spectra in reduced samples showed that two types of phosphorus signals were observed at 129.5 – 130.1 eV and 133.3 – 133.8 eV, which assigned to the reduced P species in nickel phosphide and the PO3 −4 species [21]. The reduced P species exhibited a smaller binding energy compared to that of element P (130.4 eV), implying transformation of nickel phosphide as evidenced by XRD and TEM. In addition, the peak position shifted to lower binding energies as the Ni/P molar ratio increased. These results were consistent with the report by Zhang et al. [9], due to less transfer of electron density from Ni to P atoms. In Ni 2p XPS results, the Ni 2p binding energy values of 852.7 – 853.1 eV was assigned to Ni2P or Ni12P5 or Ni3P or Ni0, while the values of 855.6 – 856.2 eV with shake-up satellite indicated the existence of Ni2+. The existence of Ni2+ species was assigned to the passivation [21]. As for the nickel phosphide catalysts, the XPS spectra showed the peak at approximately 852.8 – 853.1 eV, which was associated with Niδ+ of nickel phosphide. The peaks shifted toward a higher binding energy compared to Ni/ZrO2 catalyst indicating the transfer of electron density from Ni to P [9]. According to the XRD results (Fig. 1), the Ni2P/ZrO2 catalyst exhibited the formation of two phases in nickel phosphide; Ni2P and N12P5 on ZrO2. However, the limitation of XPS technique, the peak at approximately 852.9 eV cannot be further deconvoluted into two component peaks as the binding energy of Ni2P was very close to that of Ni12P5. In addition, binding energies of Ni in Ni2P and Ni12P5 phases were close to that of metallic Ni (852.5–852.9 eV). Hence, the presence of metallic Ni in NiP-based catalysts cannot be discarded [22]. 3.2 Catalyst performance The ZrO2, Ni/ZrO2 and NixP/ZrO2 samples were tested for their catalytic performance in the HDO of biodiesel at 350 °C under 40 bar of H2 and the experimental results are presented in Figs. 8, 9 and Table 3. The main liquid products were n-alkanes (C9-C18) and the oxygenated intermediates such as fatty alcohol (FAOH) including C16 and C18 fatty alcohols, free fatty acid (FFA) including C16 and C18 fatty acids, and wax esters. As demonstrated in Fig. 8, the blank test conducted with ZrO2 exhibited 30% FAME conversion and 17% alkane selectivity. The Lewis acid sites and oxygen vacancies of ZrO2 may involve in the adsorption and activation of the fatty acid/ester molecule of palm biodiesel to form carboxylate, which can be deoxygenated through C–C scission to generate linear hydrocarbons and carbon dioxide [27]. While by using 10%wt Ni as the catalyst, the FAME conversion increased to 46% and further increased to 50 – 88% by the addition of P to Ni/ZrO2. For each catalyst, the selectivity towards pentadecane (n-C15) and heptadecane (n-C17) were sufficiently high. The n-C15 and n-C17 alkanes contents were 20.47 – 38.28% and 22.88 – 42.82%, respectively. The main gaseous products were CO and CH4, and trace amounts of CO2 and C2 hydrocarbons were also detected. According to the product distribution obtained in the present work and those of previous references [15], the deoxygenation of palm biodiesel mainly took place via the hydrogenation of unsaturation or double bonds in palm biodiesel, followed by hydrogenolysis of saturated biodiesel to fatty acids. Then fatty acids were directly hydrogenated to C16 and C18 alkanes via HDO pathway or decarbonylized/decarboxylized to C15 and C17 alkanes by DCO and/or via DCO2 pathways with the formation of CO and CO2 as the byproducts. Then, CO and CO2 could be further hydrogenated to CH4 via methanation as shown in Eqs. (6) and (7). It should be noted that these side reactions should be avoided due to the large H2 consumption [9]. (6) CO + 3 H2 → CH4 +H2O (7) CO2 + 4 H2 → CH4 +2 H2O According to the results in Table 3, the contents of C15 and C17 alkanes were considerably higher than that of the C16 and C18 alkanes, and the DCO/DCO2 yields exhibited significantly higher than that of HDO yields. These results indicated that the deoxygenation of palm biodiesel mainly proceeded via DCO or DCO2 pathways rather than through HDO pathway. The CO/CH4 molar ratio can represent the methanation activity on the catalyst as shown in Table 3. The CO/CH4 ratios on Ni/ZrO2 was close to 0, indicating that it was more favorable for methanation. This reaction could consume large amount of H2. In contrast, the CO/CH4 ratio on NixP/ZrO2 catalysts exceeded 1, implying they had less activity for methanation. This could be due to the lower electron density of Ni atoms in the nickel phosphide catalysts, leading to less the interaction with CO and H2 [9]. These results were in good agreement with the previous report by Chen et al. [23]. As shown in Fig. 8, the conversion of the catalysts followed the sequence: Ni/ZrO2 < Ni1P/ZrO2 < Ni2P/ZrO2 < Ni3P/ZrO2 ≈ Ni4P/ZrO2, respectively. The higher conversion of the nickel phosphide catalysts could be attributed to the well metal dispersion and smaller metal particle sizes as evidenced by EDS mapping and TEM results, which enriched the amount of catalytic sites. In addition, the electronic interaction between Ni and P may also associate with the higher activity of the nickel phosphide catalysts. Due to the electron transfer from Ni to P, the Ni sites bore a small positive charge, which was more easily interact with oxygen atoms from the carbonyl group in palm biodiesel. Afterwards, the carbonyl was activated and decarbonylized to produce n-paraffin products [14]. With increasing the Ni/P molar ratios, the conversion and selectivity to alkanes gradually increased. The activity in the nickel phosphide catalysts was probably associated with the electron density of metal site [14]. Similar trends were also observed by Dupont et al. [24]. They found that without the support effects, the electron density of Ni site in Ni2P was lower than that in Ni3P and Ni12P5, leading to lower activity for DCO. Based on the XPS results, the binding energies of P 2p were 129.5 eV and 133.7 eV, corresponding to the P species in nickel phosphide and the PO4 3- species, respectively. The value of P species in nickel phosphide was lower than P element (130.4 eV), indicating the charge transfer from Ni to P leading to the decreasing of electron density on Ni site. Similarly, the values of Ni 2p binding energy were lower in NixPy than in NiO, implying the presence of Niδ+. As evidenced by XRD and TEM, the phases in Ni3PZrO2 were Ni, Ni3P, Ni12P5 and Ni2P. In contrast, the phases in Ni2P/ZrO2 were Ni2P and Ni12P5, and only Ni2P was observed for Ni1P/ZrO2. Thus, the higher activity of the Ni3P/ZrO2 catalyst could be explained by the higher electron density on Ni site, which favored DCO pathway. Although phases of NixPy observed for Ni4PZrO2 were similar to Ni3P/ZrO2, the selectivity toward n-alkanes was slightly lower. According to TEM image, the formation of large metal particles on the ZrO2 surface was observed when Ni content increased. The average particle sizes of Ni3P/ZrO2 and Ni4P/ZrO2 catalysts were 51 and 91 nm, respectively. Hence, the higher selectivity toward n-alkanes on the Ni3P/ZrO2 catalyst as compared to the Ni4P/ZrO2 catalyst could be the consequence of the smaller metal particle sizes, which enrich the number of active sites [8]. Apart from the effect of electron density, the Brønsted acid sites (PO-H sites) also influenced the deoxygenation pathway. In the present work, the branched alkanes were observed for the Ni1P/ZrO2 catalyst as shown in Fig. 9. The presence of iso-paraffin could be explained by Brønsted acid sites. This assumption agreed well with the reported by Xin et al. [25], revealing that isomerization reactions were catalyzed by Brønsted acid sites. The isomerization of n-alkanes mainly underwent through a carbenium ion intermediate that formed on the acid sites. According to NH3-TPD results, the high acidity of Ni1P/ZrO2 catalyst caused the presence branched alkanes in liquid product. According to the results above, the performance of the catalysts on deoxygenation was not only affected by the surface electron density on metal site, but also the particle sizes as well as catalyst acidity. In addition, TOF was calculated using mole of rate reacted per mole of metal and the results are summarized in Table 4. Similar to the conversion, TOF of NixP/ZrO2 catalysts was higher than that of Ni/ZrO2 catalyst. Specially, at the Ni/P ratio of 3, the TOF took value equal to 2.76 × 10−3 s−1. This TOF value of Ni3P/ZrO2 catalyst was comparable to those previously reported for FAME deoxygenation in batch mode as shown in Table 4. [26–28]. Despite exhibiting lower TOF than Ni–Ce0.6Zr0.4O2, Ni3P/ZrO2 catalyst showed higher alkane selectivity. A comparison with previous studies on the solvent and solvent-free catalytic deoxygenation is summarized in Table 4. The solvent catalytic deoxygenation usually performed at mild conditions e.g., 270–300 °C, with 90–100% conversion and 89–96% hydrocarbon selectivity [28–30]. Compared to the solvent catalytic deoxygenation, the high C15-C18 alkanes selectivity required higher reaction temperature and pressure for the solvent-free system. The Ni3P/ZrO2 catalyst prepared in this study showed significant advantage in improved alkane production, the value of hydrocarbon selectivity was similar to those of the solvent catalytic deoxygenation systems. It should be noted that the catalytic performance of the prepared Ni3P/ZrO2 catalyst could be further improved by increasing the surface area of ZrO2 to disperse nickel particles. Since the active site of catalyst markedly involves in the overall conversion. In addition, the acidity of the Ni3P/ZrO2 catalyst should be increased to improve the isomerization selectivity and endow the liquid product with good cold flow properties. Recently, Foraita et al. reported that the incorporation of SiO2 via SiO2-ZrO2 mixed oxides can improve the surface area of ZrO2 as well as induce the Brønsted acid sites. It was found that the catalytic activity of Ni and NiCu catalysts for stearic acid hydrodeoxygenation markedly improved, when using SiO2-ZrO2 mixed oxide as the support [32]. Song et al. reported that the introduction of La to Ni/ZrO2-SiO2 catalyst can additionally improve the Brønsted acid sites and promoting isomerization of hydrocarbons [33]. 3.3 Spent catalyst characterization The catalysts after the deoxygenation reaction were investigated using XRD, TG/DTG and TEM. The XRD results are shown in Fig. 1, XRD pattern of spent catalysts remain almost unchanged compared to that of the fresh catalysts, indicating that both Ni/ZrO2 and Ni3P/ZrO2 catalysts were stable under the deoxygenation testing. However, TEM analysis ( Fig. 10) showed the carbon deposition over both spent catalysts. The surface of both spent Ni/ZrO2 and Ni3P/ZrO2 catalysts were mostly surrounded by a thin layer of carbon. These results were in line with the TG/DTG analysis, as shown in Fig. 11, where the weight loss stages could be divided into two regions at approximately T < 350 °C and T > 350 °C. The weight loss stages observed at T < 350 °C can be assumed as the removal of adsorbed water and organic molecules such as palm biodiesel and reaction products, while the decomposition peak found at T > 350 °C was attributed to the decomposition of coke. For the spent Ni3P/ZrO2 catalyst, the weight loss caused by coking (1%) was lower than that of the spent Ni/ZrO2 catalyst (6%), indicating that the Ni3P/ZrO2 catalyst exhibited better resistance to carbon deposition. These results agreed well with the reported by Shi et al. [34], revealing that the presence of phosphorus improved anti-coking performance of nickel catalyst. 3.4 Reusability testing of catalyst To determine the reusability of the catalyst, the spent Ni3P/ZrO2 was washed with acetone and hexane to remove impurities on the catalyst surface and reused for the next cycle batch, with the results presented in Table 5. The conversion of the catalyst decreased approximately 5% from the fresh Ni3P/ZrO2 catalyst. According to the Fig. 1, the XRD pattern of spent catalyst remains almost unchanged compared to that of the fresh catalysts. Nevertheless, the TEM and TG/DTG results indicated carbon deposition on the spent Ni3P/ZrO2 catalyst. Hence the reason for the deactivation of the catalyst may associate with the carbon deposition. 4 Conclusions ZrO2-supported nickel phosphide bifunctional catalysts with different Ni/P molar ratios were synthesized, characterized, and tested in the solvent-free deoxygenation of palm biodiesel to produce n-paraffins in a batch reactor at 350 °C, 40 bar of H2, 5 wt% catalyst, and 5 h. Characterization of the catalysts indicated that the formation of different types of nickel phosphide species were observed in catalyst with different Ni/P molar ratio. Only Ni2P was formed with Ni/P molar ratio of 1, while Ni2P and Ni12P5 were detected when Ni/P molar ratio was 2. With further increasing Ni/P molar ratios to 3 and 4, new phases of Ni0 and Ni3P were formed in addition to those of Ni2P and Ni12P5. Modification of ZrO2-supported nickel phosphide catalyst by P resulted in a significant enhancement of catalytic activities. The increasing of both conversion and n-alkane selectivity were observed when increasing Ni/P molar ratios, which could be attributed to the higher metal dispersion, smaller metal particle size, and higher electron density on Ni site of P modified catalyst. Moreover, Ni3P/ZrO2 catalyst gave the highest conversion (88.0%) and n-alkane selectivity (95.4%) with C15 and C17 alkanes as the major components, implying that the deoxygenation process mainly proceeded through DCO/DCO2 pathways. coredata.dc:description: This study investigated the effects of Ni/P molar ratio on nickel phosphide species and on the catalytic activity on solvent-free deoxygenation of palm biodiesel to produce n-paraffins. ZrO2-supported nickel phosphide catalysts with different Ni/P molar ratio were synthesized and characterized through HRTEM, XPS, XRD, BET, NH3-TPD, and H2-TPR analysis techniques, to give an insight into the correlation of the catalyst structure and its performance. The formation of different types of nickel phosphide phases when preparing the catalyst with different Ni/P molar ratio was observed. Only Ni2P was formed with Ni/P molar ratio of 1, while Ni2P and Ni12P5 were detected when Ni/P molar ratio was 2. With further increasing Ni/P molar ratios to 3 and 4, new phases of Ni0 and Ni3P were formed in addition to those of Ni2P and Ni12P5. NixP/ZrO2 exhibited excellent catalytic performance for deoxygenation of palm biodiesel mainly via decarbonylation/decarboxylation pathways, achieving the high FAME conversion of 50.2–88.0% and n-alkane selectivity of 65.0–95.4%. Conversion and alkane selectivity of the catalysts followed the sequence: Ni3P/ZrO2 ≈ Ni4P/ZrO2 > Ni2P/ZrO2 > Ni1P/ZrO2 > Ni/ZrO2, respectively. These results suggested that Ni/P molar ratio had significantly affected on catalytic performance, which was associated with the type of nickel phosphide phase, metal dispersion, metal particle size, as well as electron density on Ni site.
coredata.dc:title: Production of bio-paraffin from solvent-free deoxygenation of palm biodiesel over ZrO2-supported nickel phosphide catalysts
